text: in this lecture we are going to see
solved problem number 12.
let's dive into the question the
question is
in the ipv4 addressing format the number
of networks allowed under class c
addresses is
and this question was asked in gate
computer science in the year 2012 and
let's see the options option a 2 power
14 option b 2 part 7 option c 2 part 21
and option d to part 24 obviously this
question is not a classless addressing
question so this is a classful
addressing question let's see the
tabular column which we had seen in the
earlier lectures this is the classes of
ip addresses we have five classes of ip
addresses class a b c d and e
and if the first octet is between 0 and
1 27 it is class a if it is between 128
and 191 it is class b if it is between
192 and 223 it is class c
now how this is identified because when
we take the first octet the first bit is
reserved in the first octet if it is 0
then it is classy if the first octet of
an ip address in binary is 1 0 then it
is class b
if the first octet of an ip address in
binary is 1 1 0 then it is classy so if
we note here class a out of eight bits
one bit is reserved in class b out of
eight bits in the first octet two bits
are reserved and in class c out of eight
bits three bits are reserved we know in
class a the first octet is the network
address though we have eight bits we can
use only seven bits right so the total
network which is possible is it's not
two point eight it's two part seven
and coming to class b the first two bits
in the first octet is fixed right so in
class b the first two octets are the
network portion and the last two octets
are the host portion so out of 32 bits
the first 16 bits are the network
portion and in that 16 bits the first
two bits are reserved so obviously 16
minus 2 is 14 so 2 power 14 networks are
possible
and coming to class c though we have
three network portion and only one host
portion out of these three network
portions that is eight plus eight plus
eight 24 bits three bits in the first
octet are reserved for identifying this
class right so out of 24 bits subtract
three bits will be getting 21 bits
obviously the number of networks that is
possible in class c is 2 part 21 and
what is the question
in ip addressing format the number of
networks allowed under class c is
out of 24 bits 21 bits can be used and 2
part 21 is the answer so the answer for
this question is to part 21
before we conclude let's see the
homework question
in the ipv4 addressing format the number
of hosts allowed under class ca
addresses is
option a 2 part 24 minus 2 option b 2
part 16 minus 2 option c 2 part 8 minus
2 and option d to part 32-2 just refer
the table or think logically and post
